title: Panel on Data Protection and Security on the Web

panelist: Maria Esther Vidal, University Simón Bolí­var

segmentation: I don't work with data protection or security, but during the last year I have been defined by having working with differing organizations in my country to define policies for data for opening data and I will summarize the results that I have so far.
OK, we all believe US team personally that knowledge is for everyone.
And that that openness and cities in collaboration should.
Help to support this initiative.

Well, that can help and support the idea that knowledge is for everyone, but that's not always the case.
There are people who can use this information and this knowledge to persecute people to harsh people and also to kill people.

I will talk about my statements.
The first is the dilemma between openness and privacy.
So if I see the definition of open data, open data is a piece of data.
Is open if anyone is free to use, reuse and distributed.
Subject only to the requirement to attribute an or share a light.
These are only the conditions that we impose to open the data, so we assume that everyone is honest.
OK, we could ensure transparency.
Probably we can avoid corruption and we call enhance public security.

Do a justify the persecution of citizens.

So we have to ensure that information about the citizens.

In some way protected and not only health related information, because there are many people.
Believe me that don't worry about health information.
There are many people that worry about other type of sensitive data.

The second statement is.
Another dilemma, collaborative systems versus security and trust.
So this is a very interesting collaborative system where people can report on illegal events.
So for example, corruption, bribery or frauds.
Also there is polar opposite.

Yeah, this is a collaborative system where citizens can upload information about politicians, an influential people, and we have an ontology to describe the data and also data mining techniques to identify potential illegal activities.
Power of groups of powers or corruption.
But the user will rely on the users on the citizens to upload the data, but they have to trust the systems.
Because they don't want to have a Trojan horse that you know captures still the data.
And also this we're systems have to trust what people have load in our systems, otherwise our discoveries will be fair, you know false.
So where are the challenge?
The challenge are first we have to be able to models process sensitive data, information about the seat city the city sends political preferences in code policies to regulate the use is defined.
Retention of according to legal constraints, citizen awareness and different meanings of private or sensitive data because not only.
Emedical data is sensitive parties, participation, consent, anonymous anonymization, normally of direct data, but also in direct reasoning.
Trust models different levels of signatures and threat models, and more important, we have to have a balance between confidentiality, integrity and availability of sensitive data.
